chaparral: Chaparral is characterized by dense, evergreen sclerophyllous shrubs adapted to Mediterranean climates.
This biome features drought-resistant plants like manzanita, chamise, and scrub oak.

The soil in chaparral regions is typically thin, rocky, and nutrient-poor.
Many chaparral plants produce flammable oils, contributing to frequent wildfires.
After fires, chaparral species like ceanothus quickly regenerate from burl-based sprouts.
Wildlife includes jackrabbits, roadrunners, and specialized reptiles like the western fence lizard.
Chaparral acts as a critical habitat for pollinators, including native bees and hummingbirds.
